docs.title: Cli name
docs.text:
mybible-cli in CLI Examples

In most command-line usage examples in this documentation, we use mybible-cli for brevity and consistency.

Your actual command may differ depending on your installation:

  • JAR file: java -jar mybible-cli.jar
  • Windows (Console version): mybible-cli-console.exe or helper scripts (mybible-cli.ps1, mybible-cli-unicode.bat, etc.)
  • Linux/macOS: /path/to/mybible-cli (full path to the binary)

Regardless of how you invoke the application, all options and subcommands work identically across platforms.

docs.title: JAR File
docs.text:
Use this option if you have Java installed on your system and know how to run applications using JAR files.

Java Runtime Requirements

To run mybible-cli.jar, you will need JRE or JDK 11 or higher.

Check your Java version: 

java -version

  1. Download mybible-cli.jar from Releases.
  2. Double-click the mybible-cli.jar if your OS supports running Java apps this way. This will open the GUI where you can type the reference and select the module. You may also start the GUI with the reference and the module preselected: 
    # Enter the directory with mybible-cli.jar
cd Downloads

# Start the GUI with the reference and the module preselected
java -jar mybible-cli.jar gui -m KJV -r "John 3:16"
  3. To get the output in the terminal window, use the required CLI options: 
    # Enter the directory with mybible-cli.jar
cd Downloads

# Get the required text by specifying the reference and the module
java -jar mybible-cli.jar get -m KJV -r "John 3:16"

docs.title: Module Usage
docs.text:
CLIGUI Using Quotation Marks

If the module name you want to use contains special characters or spaces, always specify it in quotation marks.

The same is true for references, unless you want to fetch verses from an entire book.

Examples: 

# No special characters/spaces in the module name or reference
mybible-cli get -m KJV+ -r Lk

# With special character and spaces
mybible-cli get -m "НПУ'22" -r "Luke 2:2"

docs.title: Fetch a Single Verse
docs.text:
mybible-cli get -m KJV+ -r "John 3:16"

Output: 

John 3:16 For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.

docs.title: Fetch Multiple Verses
docs.text: mybible-cli get -m ESV -r "Romans 8:28-30"

docs.title: Fetch Multiple Passages
docs.text: mybible-cli get -m NET -r "John 3:16; Romans 8:28; Ephesians 2:8-10"

docs.title: Fetch Verses
docs.text:
Launch the GUI by opening the application from the Start menu, double-clicking the JAR file, or from the terminal:

# Start with an empty output
mybible-cli

# Or with a pre-loaded passage:
mybible-cli gui -m KJV+ -r "John 3:16"

In the GUI:

  1. Select a module from the dropdown.

  2. Enter a reference, for example:

    • John 3:16
    • Romans 8:28-30
    • John 3:16; Ephesians 2:8-10; 1 Peter-2 Peter 2:1

    This can be one verse, several verses, several chapters, or several passages, including entire books.

  3. Press Enter or click "Show".

docs.title: Need modules
docs.text:
You'll Need MyBible Modules

To use this application, you need at least one unpacked MyBible module (.sqlite3 file). See MyBible Modules for detailed information on finding, downloading, and using modules.

docs.title: Set module path
docs.text:
CLIGUI 
mybible-cli list --path "/path/to/your/MyBible/modules"

Example paths:

WindowsmacOSLinux 
mybible-cli list --path "C:\Users\YourName\Documents\MyBible\modules"

mybible-cli list --path "$HOME/Documents/MyBible/modules"

mybible-cli list --path "$HOME/MyBible/modules"
  1. Launch the GUI by opening the application from the Start menu, double-clicking the JAR file, or from the terminal: 
    mybible-cli

  2. Click "Set Module Path".

  3. If you selected the correct folder, you will be able to see the list of modules sorted by language.

Setting the module path needs to be done only once. The path will be saved for future use.

Switch module folder

If you need to switch to a different module folder, simply repeat the above and specify the folder you want to use.

docs.title: List Available Modules
docs.text:
mybible-cli list

You should see your modules sorted by language:

docs.title: CLI and GUI Tool to Get Text from MyBible Modules
docs.text: Welcome to the documentation for MyBible-CLI (mybible-cli) — a fast, cross-platform command-line and GUI tool for accessing biblical text from MyBible modules.

docs.title: About MyBible-CLI
docs.text:
MyBible-CLI is a small utility designed to retrieve biblical text from MyBible modules on a desktop operating system without running the MyBible mobile app.

MyBible-CLI is inspired by diatheke, a command-line tool for Crosswire Sword modules. While diatheke is quite powerful and convenient, it works only with Crosswire Sword modules and does not support the MyBible format, which has an extensive library of high-quality modules.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
This tool is designed as a quick lookup tool for biblical text, not a comprehensive Bible study application. It excels at:

  • Fast text retrieval for use in other applications
  • Scriptable access to biblical text
  • Integration into automated workflows
  • Quick reference lookups

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Fast Verse Retrieval: Quickly fetch and display verses from any MyBible module
  • Flexible Formatting: Control output with customizable format strings
  • Book Name Mappings: Use default abbreviations or create custom mappings
  • Dual Interface: Use via command line for scripting or GUI for interactive lookups
  • Cross-Platform: Works on Windows, macOS, and Linux

docs.title: Examples & Recipes
docs.text:
Fix Garbled Terminal Output on Windows

If your output is garbled...

  • ...and you use mybible-cli-console.exe

    Use one of the helper scripts instead of mybible-cli-console.exe:

    • mybible-cli.ps1
    • mybible-cli-unicode.bat
    • mybible-cli-utf8.bat

    All of them accept the same options and arguments as mybible-cli-console.exe.

  • ...and you use mybible-cli.jar

    Start Java with additional runtime options:

    java "-Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 -Dsun.stdout.encoding=UTF-8" -jar mybible-cli.jar get -r "Jn 3:16"
Create Shell Alias on macOS and Linux

  • Make it possible to run mybible-cli without giving the full path.

    Add to your ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc: 

    # If using JAR
alias mybible-cli='java -jar /path/to/mybible-cli.jar'

# Otherwise
alias mybible-cli='/path/to/mybible-cli'

  • Fetch verses even faster: 

    alias bible='mybible-cli get'

  • Now you can use: 

    bible -r "John 3:16"

Daily Provers Script 
#!/bin/bash
# daily-verse.sh
DAY=$(date +%d)
mybible-cli get -m ESV -r "Proverbs $DAY"
Search in Output 
mybible-cli get -m KJV+ -r "John 1" | grep -i "word"
Count Words in Passage 
mybible-cli get -m ESV -r "Genesis 1" -f "%z" | wc -w

docs.title: Output Formatting
docs.text: Both the GUI and CLI use a powerful format string to control the appearance of the output.

docs.title: Rendering: CLI vs. GUI
docs.text:
The output rendering is optimized for each environment:

  • CLI mode: Specifiers %X, %Y, and %Z use ANSI color codes for a rich display directly in your terminal.

  • GUI mode: These same specifiers render as rich text. The fonts, colors, and styles for different elements (like verse numbers or words of Jesus) can be fully customized in the configuration dialog.

docs.title: JSON Output
docs.text:
Both modes also support outputting the requested reference text as raw JSON data.

  • CLI: Using the --json flag outputs the JSON to standard output. This can be helpful if you need structured output for further post-processing.
  • GUI: Selecting the "Raw JSON" checkbox renders the JSON in the text area. This is useful for quickly inspecting a module's raw content, such as verifying the presence of Strong's numbers, footnotes, or other formatting tags.

In both cases, the JSON contains the unprocessed verse text, identical to the output of the %T format specifier.

docs.title: Format Specifiers
docs.text:
The following specifiers can be used in the format string:

Specifier Description Reference %a Default abbreviated book name (e.g., 'Jn') %f Default full book name (e.g., 'John') %A Module-specific abbreviated book name %F Module-specific full book name %b Book number per MyBible specifications (e.g., 500 for John) %c Chapter number %v Verse number %m Module name Text Content %T Raw verse text, including all original module markup %t Cleaned, multi-line plain text with paragraph breaks preserved %z Cleaned, single-line plain text with all tags and breaks removed Formatted Text %X Multi-line text with formatting and Strong's numbers and morphological data, if present %Y Multi-line text with formatting, without Strong's numbers and morphological data %Z Single-line text with formatting, without Strong's numbersand morphological data

Extra Text in the Format String

In addition to the specifiers, you can use any other characters in the format string.

  • \n is rendered as a new line
  • \t is rendered as a tab
  • everything else is rendered literally

docs.title: How to Set the Format String
docs.text:
CLIGUI

The default format string is "%A %c:%v %t".

You can override it in two ways:

  • For a single command: Use the -f flag: 

    mybible-cli get -r "Jn 3:16" -f "%f %c:%v %Y"

  • To set a new default: Use the -F flag. This saves the format string to your configuration file for all future commands: 

    mybible-cli get -r "Jn 3:16" -F "%F %c:%v %t"

Using Formatted Output in Scripts

The %X, %Y, and %Z specifiers include ANSI color codes for better readability in the terminal. These codes can interfere with scripting or when piping output to tools like grep. To strip all formatting and get clean text, simply add the --no-ansi flag. 

# Get clean text with Strong's numbers, suitable for scripting
mybible-cli get -m KJV+ -r "Jn 3:16" -f "%f %c:%v %X" --no-ansi

The default format string is "%A %c:%v %Y".

To change it:

  1. Press the Configure button.
  2. Enter your custom string in the "Format String" field.

The field's tooltip provides a quick reference for each specifier. The same info can be accessed by pressing the Details... button next to the field to open a help dialog.

docs.title: Pre-built Application
docs.text:
Use this option if you don't have Java installed on your system.

WindowsmacOSLinux

On Windows, you may use one of two versions (or both):

  1. Download mybible-cli-macOS.zip from Releases.
  2. Unzip the downloaded file.
  3. Drag the unzipped application to the Applications folder.

  4. Right-click and select "Open" the first time (security requirement).

    macOS Security Warning

    If your macOS complains that the application cannot be opened because it is from an unidentified developer:

    1. Right-click the application.
    2. Select "Open".
    3. Open "System Settings" from the menu.
    4. Navigate to the "Privacy & Security" section.
    5. Select "mybible-cli.app" and click "Open anyway".

  5. The application can be used in both CLI and GUI modes.

    To start the GUI, simply open the application.

    To use the CLI, run with the required CLI options: 

    /Applications/mybible-cli.app/Contents/MacOS/mybible-cli get -m KJV -r "Jn 3:16"

Pre-built binaries are available only for Debian-based distros.

  1. Download mybible-cli-Linux-DEB.zip from Releases.
  2. Unzip the downloaded file.
  3. Install the unzipped .deb file: 
    sudo dpkg -i mybible-cli_<version>_amd64.deb ## Replace <version> with the actual version number

  4. The application can be used in both CLI and GUI modes.

    To start the GUI, simply open the application from the application menu in your DE.

    To use the CLI, run with the required CLI options: 

    /opt/mybible-cli/bin/mybible-cli get -m KJV -r "Jn 3:16"

docs.title: CLI and GUI Version
docs.text:
Installation Steps This version can output biblical text in both modes (GUI always opens with or from a terminal window).
  1. Download mybible-cli-Windows-Console.zip from Releases. This is a zipped portable application.
  2. Unpack the portable version.
  3. Place the unpacked portable application in a convenient location.
  4. Run the application by double-clicking mybible-cli-console.exe to launch it in GUI mode, or run in the terminal: 
    :: Enter the directory with mybible-cli
cd C:\Programs\mybible-cli-console

:: Get the biblical text
mybible-cli-console.exe get -m KJV -r "John 3:16"

docs.title: GUI-Only Version
docs.text:
Installation Steps This version outputs biblical text only in GUI mode.
  1. Download mybible-cli-Windows-GUI.zip from Releases. This is a zipped MSI installer.
  2. Unpack and run the installer.
  3. Select the installation destination, or accept the suggested one.

  4. Run the application by clicking the mybible-cli icon in the Start menu. This will open the GUI where you can type the reference and select the module. You may also start the GUI with the reference and the module preselected: 

    :: Enter the directory with mybible-cli
cd C:\Program Files\mybible-cli

:: Start the GUI with the reference and the module preselected
mybible-cli.exe gui -m KJV -r "John 3:16"

    The GUI-only version of the application cannot be used to retrieve biblical text in command-line mode. Use the portable CLI and GUI Version.

docs.title: MyBible Modules
docs.text: This page explains what MyBible modules are, where to get them, and how to manage them with mybible-cli.

docs.title: What are MyBible Modules?
docs.text:
MyBible modules are SQLite database files (.sqlite3 extension) containing biblical text and related content. They follow the MyBible format specification and can include:

  • Biblical text in various translations
  • Book names and metadata
  • Optional features such as Strong's numbers, morphological data, cross-references, and footnotes

docs.title: Module Types
docs.text:
MyBible format specification supports several types of modules. More information about module types can be found at mybible.zone/modules.

Note

mybible-cli is designed specifically for Bible text retrieval, not Bible study. Only Bible modules are supported.

docs.title: Supported by mybible-cli
docs.text: • ✅ Bible text modules - Translations of the Bible (complete or partial)

docs.title: Not Supported
docs.text:
• ❌ Commentary modules
  • ❌ Dictionary modules
  • ❌ Devotional modules
  • ❌ Other non-Bible content types

docs.title: Web Download: ph4.org
docs.text:
A convenient place to browse and download MyBible modules is ph4.org Bible section.

  • Browsable collection of multiple Bible translations
  • Direct downloads
  • Easy access to modules in various languages
Mobile App Sources

The MyBible app for Android and iOS downloads modules from several dedicated repositories, but they don't have a web interface for browsing.

docs.title: Command-Line Module Manager: mybible-get
docs.text:
If you're comfortable with command-line tools and have Python installed, you can use mybible-get – a command-line module manager similar to apt, brew, or choco.

Important: Use Separate Folders

Modules managed by mybible-get and modules downloaded/unpacked manually should be kept in separate folders to avoid conflicts.

mybible-get can:

  • Search for modules
  • Download modules directly from repositories used by the MyBible mobile app
  • Update existing modules
  • Maintain mulpiple module collections

docs.title: Installing Modules
docs.text:
Manual Download and ExtractUsing mybible-get

Note

See the mybible-get documentation for complete usage instructions.

If you have Python installed:

# Install mybible-get
pipx install mybible-get

docs.title: Step 1: Download
docs.text:
1. Visit ph4.org Bible section
  2. Browse or search for your desired translation
  3. Download the .zip file

docs.title: Step 2: Extract
docs.text: Unzip the downloaded file to get the .sqlite3 file

docs.title: Step 3: Organize
docs.text:
Create a dedicated folder for your modules

# Recommended structure
MyBible/
└── modules/
    ├── KJV.sqlite3
    ├── NET.sqlite3
    ├── ESV.sqlite3
    └── ...

docs.title: Step 1: Tell mybible-get where your modules need to be located:
docs.text:
# Set a separate folder for mybible-get modules (will be created if needed)
mybible-get set-path ~/MyBible-modules

docs.title: Step 2: Install modules
docs.text:
# Search for modules using the module name
mybible-get search -n KJV

# Install a module using one or more of the search results
mybible-get install KJV1611, KJV+

    • John 3:16

    • John 3:16; Ephesians 2:8-10; 1 Peter-2 Peter 2:1

    This can be one verse, several verses, several chapters, or several passages, including entire books.

  3. Press Enter or click "Show".

docs.title: Default Module
docs.text:
The last used module is remembered for both CLI and GUI. After using a module once, you can omit -m:

# First use
mybible-cli get -m KJV+ -r "Psalm 23"

# Subsequent uses (KJV+ is now default)
mybible-cli get -r "John 1:1"

docs.title: Module Features
docs.text:
Some modules include enhanced features:

  • Strong's Numbers - Original Hebrew/Greek word references
  • Morphological Data - Grammatical information
  • Footnotes - Translator notes and variants
  • Formatting - Bold, italics, etc.
  • Words of Jesus

To control how these features are displayed, use format specifiers. See Output Formatting for details.

Footnotes are always omitted in the output.

Check Module Features

The raw verse text (rawVerseText in JSON or %T format specifier) may be used to check what features a module includes: 

# Regular output
mybible-cli get -m KJV -r "John 1:1" -f "%T"

# JSON output
mybible-cli get -m KJV -r "John 1:1" --json

Look for tags like:

  • <S>G3056</S> - Strong's numbers
  • <f>footnote reference</f> - Footnotes
  • <J>text</J> - Words of Jesus

docs.title: Module Book Names
docs.text:
Each module defines its own book names (both full and abbreviated). You can:

  • Use default international book abbreviations
  • Use module-specific abbreviations with -A flag in CLI, or by checking the "Use Bible Book Names from the Selected Module" checkbox in GUI
  • Use custom mapping files with -a flag in CLI, or by selecting the file for "Bible Book Names" in GUI
  • Specify a language for book name recognition with -l flag in CLI, or by specifying the language code in the "Names Lookup Language" field in GUI

See Book Name Mapping for complete details on customizing book name recognition.

docs.title: Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Get up and running with mybible-cli in minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
To start using mybible-cli, you need to make sure that:

  1. It's present on your computer – see Installation Guide.
  2. You have at least one unpacked MyBible module – see MyBible Modules.

docs.title: First-time Setup
docs.text:
The only absolutely necessary thing that needs to be done prior to the first use is telling the application where your MyBible modules are stored.

If you have one folder with modules, this needs to be done only once.

If you have multiple folders with modules and want to switch between them, setting the module path needs to be done once before each switch.

The application uses the same configuration file regardless of the mode it runs in (CLI or GUI) or how it was launched (from terminal, in a script, as a JAR file, as a compiled OS-specific application, etc.).

mybible-cli in CLI Examples

In most command-line usage examples in this documentation, we use mybible-cli for brevity and consistency.

Your actual command may differ depending on your installation:

  • JAR file: java -jar mybible-cli.jar
  • Windows (Console version): mybible-cli-console.exe or helper scripts (mybible-cli.ps1, mybible-cli-unicode.bat, etc.)
  • Linux/macOS: /path/to/mybible-cli (full path to the binary)

Regardless of how you invoke the application, all options and subcommands work identically across platforms.

docs.title: Set Module Path
docs.text:
CLIGUI 
mybible-cli list --path "/path/to/your/MyBible/modules"

Example paths:

WindowsmacOSLinux 
mybible-cli list --path "C:\Users\YourName\Documents\MyBible\modules"

mybible-cli list --path "$HOME/Documents/MyBible/modules"

mybible-cli list --path "$HOME/MyBible/modules"
  1. Launch the GUI by opening the application from the Start menu, double-clicking the JAR file, or from the terminal: 
    mybible-cli

  2. Click "Set Module Path".

  3. If you selected the correct folder, you will be able to see the list of modules sorted by language.

Setting the module path needs to be done only once. The path will be saved for future use.

Switch module folder

If you need to switch to a different module folder, simply repeat the above and specify the folder you want to use.

docs.title: List Available Modules
docs.text:
mybible-cli list

You should see your modules sorted by language:

docs.title: Module Usage
docs.text:
CLIGUI Using Quotation Marks

If the module name you want to use contains special characters or spaces, always specify it in quotation marks.

The same is true for references, unless you want to fetch verses from an entire book.

Examples: 

# No special characters/spaces in the module name or reference
mybible-cli get -m KJV+ -r Lk

# With special character and spaces
mybible-cli get -m "НПУ'22" -r "Luke 2:2"

docs.title: Fetch a Single Verse
docs.text:
mybible-cli get -m KJV+ -r "John 3:16"

Output: 

John 3:16 For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.

docs.title: Fetch Multiple Verses
docs.text: mybible-cli get -m ESV -r "Romans 8:28-30"

docs.title: Fetch Multiple Passages
docs.text: mybible-cli get -m NET -r "John 3:16; Romans 8:28; Ephesians 2:8-10"

docs.title: Fetch Verses
docs.text:
Launch the GUI by opening the application from the Start menu, double-clicking the JAR file, or from the terminal:

# Start with an empty output
mybible-cli

# Or with a pre-loaded passage:
mybible-cli gui -m KJV+ -r "John 3:16"

In the GUI:

  1. Select a module from the dropdown.

  2. Enter a reference, for example:

    • John 3:16
    • Romans 8:28-30
    • John 3:16; Ephesians 2:8-10; 1 Peter-2 Peter 2:1

    This can be one verse, several verses, several chapters, or several passages, including entire books.

  3. Press Enter or click "Show".

docs.title: Read a Chapter
docs.text:
CLIGUI 
mybible-cli get -m ESV -r "Psalm 23"
  1. Press Ctrl+L / Cmd+L or click in the "Bible Reference" field.
  2. Enter the reference, and change the module if needed.
  3. Press Enter or click "Show".

docs.title: Read Multiple Chapters
docs.text:
CLIGUI 
mybible-cli get -m KJV -r "Matthew 5-7"
  1. Press Ctrl+L / Cmd+L or click in the "Bible Reference" field
  2. Enter the reference, and change the module if needed
  3. Press Enter or click "Show".

docs.title: Copy Output to Clipboard
docs.text:
CLIGUI WindowsmacOSLinux 
mybible-cli get -m NET -r "Romans 8:28" | clip

mybible-cli get -m NET -r "Romans 8:28" | pbcopy

mybible-cli get -m NET -r "Romans 8:28" | xclip -selection clipboard
  1. Type the required reference and select the module.
  2. Press Enter or click "Show".

  3. Press Ctrl+Shift+C / Cmd+Shift+C or click "Copy Text".

docs.title: Save to File
docs.text:
CLIGUI 
mybible-cli get -m KJV -r "Psalm 119" > psalm119.txt
  1. Type the required reference and select the module.
  2. Press Enter or click "Show".
  3. Press Ctrl+Shift+C / Cmd+Shift+C or click "Copy Text".
  4. Launch a text editor or a word processor, and create a new document.
  5. Paste the copied content. If the application supports extended formatting, some formatting will be kept.
  6. Save the newly created document.

docs.title: Get JSON Output
docs.text:

Output: 

[

    "bookNumber": 500,

    "moduleFullBookName": "John",

docs.title: Using the GUI
docs.text: The mybible-cli graphical user interface (GUI) offers a powerful and intuitive way to read, study, and customize your Bible text display without using the command line. It is ideal for interactive browsing and deep customization of the look and feel.

docs.title: Main Interface Overview
docs.text:
The GUI is designed for ease of use with three primary components:

  • Text Display Area: The main pane where the formatted Bible text appears.
  • Reference Input: A text field where you enter the Bible reference (e.g., "John 3:16").
  • Module Selector: A dropdown list to choose your desired Bible translation.

docs.title: Fetching Verses
docs.text: To look up a passage, simply select a module, type a reference into the input field, and press the Show button or hit Enter.

docs.title: Automatic Updates
docs.text: The GUI is designed to be responsive. Changing the selected module in the dropdown list will automatically refresh the displayed text to show the same reference from the new module.

docs.title: Copying Text with Formatting
docs.text:
A key feature of the GUI is its advanced copy functionality. When you copy text from the display area (Ctrl+Shift+C / Cmd+Shift+C or via the Copy button), it places both plain text and rich text onto the clipboard.

This allows you to paste into any application:

  • Plain Text: Paste into a simple text editor.
  • Rich Text: Paste into a word processor or email client, preserving all fonts, colors, and styles.

docs.title: Configuration and Customization
docs.text: The heart of GUI customization lies in the Configuration dialog, accessible by pressing the Configure button.

docs.title: Look&Feel and Themes
docs.text:
The GUI includes several built-in Look and Feels (LAFs) that change the overall appearance of the application, from button styles to window chrome.

Furthermore, you can save all your custom style and color settings as a Theme. Themes can be exported, shared with other users, and imported, allowing you to maintain a consistent look across different computers or share your favorite style.

docs.title: Customizing Fonts and Colors
docs.text:
You have granular control over the appearance of the text display area. In the Configuration dialog, you can customize:

  • The background color of the text area.
  • The fonts, styles, and colors for various parts of the text, including:
    • Reference elements (book, chapter, verse number, other text, i.e. :).
    • The main biblical text.
    • Words of Jesus.
    • Alternative biblical text (useful for interlinear translations).
    • Strong's numbers.
    • Morphological data.

docs.title: Module and Book Name Settings
docs.text:
The GUI provides easy access to manage where your modules are stored and how book names are recognized.

  • Module Path: You can easily set the directory where mybible-cli looks for your .sqlite3 files. For detailed instructions, see how to Set Module Path.
  • Book Name Mapping: The GUI supports using custom mapping files and language settings for book name lookups, just like the CLI. For detailed instructions, see Bible Book Names.

docs.title: Extending Functionality
docs.text:
The Extension Manager, found in the Configuration dialog, lets you install and remove packages to enhance the application. You can add:

  • Application translations
  • Book name mapping files for various languages
  • Custom GUI themes

For more information, see Extensions.

docs.title: GUI Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text:
The mybible-cli graphical user interface (GUI) provides several keyboard shortcuts to speed up your workflow and provide quick access to common actions. These shortcuts help you navigate the application and perform tasks without using the mouse.

Windows / Linux macOS Action Esc Esc Quit the application Ctrl+L Cmd+L Focus the "Bible reference" input field Enter Enter Fetch verses for the reference in the input field Ctrl+M Cmd+M Focus the "Module" dropdown list Ctrl+J Cmd+J Toggle raw JSON output Ctrl+Shift+C Cmd+Shift+C Copy displayed text (with rich text formatting) Cmd+, Open the Configuration dialog

docs.title: Програма для отримання текстів з модулів MyBible
docs.text: Перед вами документація до програми MyBible-CLI (mybible-cli) — швидкого, кросплатформенного інструменту командного рядка з додатковим графічним інтерфейсом для отримання біблійних текстів з модулів MyBible.

docs.title: Про програму MyBible-CLI
docs.text:
MyBible-CLI is a small utility designed to retrieve biblical text from MyBible modules on a desktop operating system without running the MyBible mobile app.

MyBible-CLI is inspired by diatheke, a command-line tool for Crosswire Sword modules. While diatheke is quite powerful and convenient, it works only with Crosswire Sword modules and does not support the MyBible format, which has an extensive library of high-quality modules.

Ця програма стала можливою завдяки ґрунтовній праці та відданості багатьох людей і проектів. Особливі подяки:

  • Crosswire Sword Project - For the inspiration provided by the diatheke tool.

docs.title: Format Specifiers
docs.text:
The following specifiers can be used in the format string:

Specifier Description Reference %a Типова скорочена назва книги (наприклад, 'Jn') %f Типова повна назва книги (наприклад, 'John') %A Скорочена назва книги, визначена у файлі модуля %F Повна назва книги, визначена у файлі модуля %b Book number per MyBible specifications (e.g., 500 for John) %c Номер розділу %v Номер вірша %m Назва модуля Text Content %T Raw verse text, including all original module markup %t Cleaned, multi-line plain text with paragraph breaks preserved %z Cleaned, single-line plain text with all tags and breaks removed Formatted Text %X Multi-line text with formatting and Strong's numbers and morphological data, if present %Y Multi-line text with formatting, without Strong's numbers and morphological data %Z Single-line text with formatting, without Strong's numbersand morphological data

Extra Text in the Format String

In addition to the specifiers, you can use any other characters in the format string. * \n is rendered as a new line * \t is rendered as a tab * everything else is rendered literally

docs.title: Встановлення
docs.text:
Learn how to install mybible-cli on different platforms.

You'll Need MyBible Modules

To use this application, you need at least one unpacked MyBible module (.sqlite3 file). See MyBible Modules for detailed information on finding, downloading, and using modules.

docs.title: Installation Methods
docs.text:
• Pre-built Application
  • Файл JAR
  • Building from Source

docs.title: JAR File
docs.text:
Use this option if you have Java installed on your system and know how to run applications using JAR files.

Java Runtime Requirements

To run mybible-cli.jar, you will need JRE or JDK 11 or higher.

Check your Java version: 

java -version

  1. Download mybible-cli.jar from Releases.
  2. Double-click the mybible-cli.jar if your OS supports running Java apps this way. This will open the GUI where you can type the reference and select the module. You may also start the GUI with the reference and the module preselected: 
    # Enter the directory with mybible-cli.jar
cd Downloads
# Start the GUI with the reference and the module preselected
java -jar mybible-cli.jar gui -m KJV -r "John 3:16"
  3. To get the output in the terminal window, use the required CLI options: 
    # Enter the directory with mybible-cli.jar
cd Downloads
# Get the required text by specifying the reference and the module
java -jar mybible-cli.jar get -m KJV -r "John 3:16"

docs.title: Building from Source
docs.text:
If you consider this option, you probably know why and when to use it.

Java Development Kit Requirements

To build the application, you will need JDK version 17 or higher.

  1. Clone the mybible-cli-java repository:

    git clone https://github.com/kosivantsov/mybible-cli-java.git

  2. Build the JAR:

    ./gradlew clean shadowJar

  3. Run the application:

    # Launch the GUI
java -jar build/jpackage/mybible-cli.jar
# Launch the GUI with the preselected reference and module:
java -jar build/jpackage/mybible-cli.jar gui -m KJV -r "Jn 3:16"
# Or use in the terminal
java -jar build/jpackage/mybible-cli.jar get -m KJV -r "Jn 3:16"

docs.text:

Ctrl+J Cmd+J Ввімкнути виведення необробленого JSON Ctrl+Shift+C Cmd+Shift+C Копіювати показаний текст (з розширеним форматуванням) Cmd+, Відкрити діалогове вікно налаштування
